abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, with substantial
            institutional development impacts, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank, and Borrower. Lessons
            reinforce that institutional reform projects such as this
            one, can be successful in building capacities to support the
            private agricultural sector, even when government has lagged
            in reforming trade, and price policies, privatization of
            agro-kombinats, and state-owned land, as well as for other
            policies, fundamental to long-run market-oriented
            agriculture sector development. Basically, projects designed
            to improve institutional performance, can be implemented
            before economic reforms are completed. Another lesson
            conveys that if an agricultural institutional development
            project is to be evaluated in terms of quantified impacts on
            farmer incomes, (1) the difficulty of this must be
            recognized, (2) the logic of the quantification must
            therefore be specified in detail early on, (3) the project
            must not become effective until precise, defined baseline
            data to support the evaluation are available, (4) data
            collection, and monitoring must be rigorously implemented
            during the project, and, (5) all these expensive monitoring
            and evaluation activities, must be adequately financed as
            part of the project. Competitive grant schemes financed by
            the project, show that useful research can be developed, and
            transferred to farmers. However, experience also suggests
            that effective competitive grant management requires strong,
            independent supervision, and regular financial, and
            scientific auditing. In this context, farmer representation
            on advisory boards is often notional, and rarely democratic,
            while research, and program supervision is often under
            funded, and insufficiently independent. To be effective in
            satisfying the research needs of small private farmers in
            the long run, the government should therefore, start an
            ongoing process of reform.
